instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power corrosion on <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>
threads.message:
hello everyone im working on a water damage  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no power. It has green light on magsafe but no fan spin. during visual inspection i found heavy corrosion on <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> (sst25vf064c)

1) can this chip prevent the board from booting up? 
2) what is the purpose of this chip?

thanks,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power corrosion on <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>
threads.message:
1. Yes it can, but it's likely not the chip but the traces or resistors near it.
2. That is the BIOS chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power corrosion on <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>
threads.message: Very much a problem! Usually the traces are corroded and also the resistors that are in the data lines. Look up "termination resistors" in the schematic around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and verify the traces and resistors are  good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power corrosion on <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>
threads.message: i was able to fix this board by replacing that component. it was required for boot

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power corrosion on <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>
threads.message: Did you transfer the ME Region??? If not this isnâ€™t fixed!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power corrosion on <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>
threads.message: i just took that chip from a donor board and its working perfectly. isn't the ME region stored in the bios chip?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power corrosion on <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>
threads.message: Yes! You cannot simply just put a new BIOS on and say good to go on the newer i5 and i7 machines!!! You need to read the old chip to transfer the ME OR set the new chip up with a clean ME. Duke can help you on that he's a boss at it. But NEVER just put a new BIOS on an send it off unless it's the old C2D machines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power corrosion on <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>
threads.message:
thanks for your input John but <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> is not the bios chip. Its a simple logic gate it provides the (cs) chip select for the bios. The device won't work without it. so its not necessary to transfer the ME region. Duke, please correct me if I'm wrong

[URL="https://assets.nexperia.com/documents/data-sheet/74LVC1G99.pdf"]https://assets.nexperia.com/docu.../data-sheet/74LVC1G99.pdf[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power corrosion on <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>
threads.message: <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> IS the BIOS chip. <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> is the logic gate that does what you just said. If you replaced <CHIP>U6101</CHIP>, then you are ok. If you replaced <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, then you are not ok.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power corrosion on <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>
threads.message: You cannot just replace <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> off another board like that! The ME region needs to be fixed and serial/model numbers should be fixed too.
